newsitem.title: USA: Brent steady late, US foreign crudes still ample.
newsitem.headline: Brent steady late, US foreign crudes still ample.

text.p: North Sea Brent was steady in late U.S. trading Wednesday amid moderate selling by a major European company, trade sources said.
A partial paper March Brent changed hands at $22.42 a barrel, down one cent from the IPE settlement.
April partials traded three times at $21.92 and once at $21.95, down five to seven cents from the London close, traders said.
Feb/March brent was dealt at 38 cents a barrel, while March/April moved at 45 cents, they said.
Meanwhile, North Sea and West African crudes continue to rain on the U.S. Gulf Coast, reflecting the open transatlantic arbitrage.
The spread between Brent and West Texas Intermediate/Cushing for March was around $1.65-75 a barrel, down about five cents from late Wednesday but still high enough to encourage transatlantic trade.
A European company is offering Brent for early March delivery into the Gulf Coast at March WTI minus 30 cents, traders said.
Two Nigerian Qua Iboe cargoes are on offer for late February and mid-March at around March WTI plus 40-50 cents delivered, traders said.
Latin American crudes such as Colombian Cusiana have crumbled under the weight of this transatlantic influx.
A European company sold Cusiana for February 6-7 to a Gulf Coast refiner at March WTI minus 65 cents a barrel fob, down about five cents from the last transaction.
State-owned Ecopetrol sold a separate Cusiana into the Gulf Coast at a discount of 45-50 cents a barrel, but that price is likely to come off of the April marker, traders said.
Some traders are warning of imminent oversupply in the Gulf Coast.
"The buying requirements have moved from market to market, delaying the supply glut that's coming any day," one trader said. "Eventually it'll rain, and we'll have an oversupply situation."
